reporting-org.narrative: UTZ - joined forces with Rainforest Alliance

title.narrative: Building Capacities for Sector change: country program Kenya

description.narrative: In 2020 we will have strengthened the lobby and advocacy capacity of civil society organizations in Kenya on farmer group strengthening, climate change and water, and living wage. As a result we will see an improvement of policy environment (both government and companies) and support services in these countries related to these themes. These themes are: 1. Smallholder inclusion & farmer group strengthening The aim is to increase the inclusion of smallholders in supply-chain driven sustainability programs. Strengthening farmer organizations is seen as an important way to increase the bargaining power of smallholder farmers in the supply chain. 2. Women’s empowerment and gender The goal is to increase the inclusion of women in certification and access to benefits as well as to reduce discrimination and violence against women. 3. Climate and water The focus is on up scaling of best practices in smallholder adaptation to climate change and sustainable water use. 4. Living wage The goal is to improve wages of workers on coffee and tea estates towards a living wage.
SP-KEN Building Capacities for Sector change: country program Kenya

title.narrative: Country Scan

description.narrative: During the first part of the inception phase of the program (December 2015-March 2016) UTZ Country Representatives / SP focal points, supported by external consultants and UTZ Amsterdam staff, carried out a deeper analysis of the sector(s) and themes proposed for their countries to develop a more focused approach for the SP program. The objective of the Country Scans was “to provide a situational analysis on each sector and theme per country assessing the current state with regards to the relevant thematic SP objectives, clearly formulating the causes of the problem that need addressing and identify opportunities for interventions and provide recommendations on potential partners for these interventions.” The Country Scan documents are based on our own experience in the countries, but also document review, conversations/interviews with experts, key informants including Dutch embassy staff, national and international organizations, and workshop results with many of these actors.

title.narrative: # of country scans

comment.narrative: 1 country scan is completed for Kenya
10-01-2018: 1 country scan completed for Kenya

title.narrative: Country Plan

description.narrative: During the second part of the inception phase of the program (April-July 2016) UTZ Country Representatives / SP focal points, supported by external consultants and UTZ Amsterdam staff in drafting the country plans. The purpose of the SP country program plan is to set out a strategic direction for sector change in the country and serves as a framework. This plan clearly states UTZ goals for the country the Theory of Change to guide interventions as well as the budget for said activities. Overall, the SP Country Plan will serve as a guide for the next years, as well as a basis for the year plans that will be formulated for 2017 to 2020.

title.narrative: # of country plans

comment.narrative: 1 country plan is completed for Kenya
10-01-2018: 1 country plan is completed for Kenya

title.narrative: Ultimate Outcome 1: Improved inclusion of the voice of female and male smallholders and workers

description.narrative: Improved inclusion of the voice of female and male smallholders and workers in policy/law-making processes

title.narrative: DD3 # of more inclusive policy/law-making processes

description.narrative: Voices, needs and interests of male and female farmers, smallholders and workers are better included in the development of policies and services

comment.narrative: 04-06-2019: 1: Living wage/wage setting:Plantation owners of Ibonia and Kirimiri coffee estates are willing to disclose their audited books of accounts. MOU sare signed with details and agreements 18 feb 2018 & 2 coffee byuers shared market information 2: KCPA developed the Coffee Roadmap 2018 -2019 and presented it to the Ministry of Agriculture. The roadmap was subsequently presented to the Cabinet for Approval 3. Ministry of Agriculture in Nakuru and Nyeri Counties Establised of local county platforms

29-04-2020: 1. Coffee Sector Implementation Committtee (CSIC) invited KCPA as a farmer representative to share their views on the coffee sale regulations. 2. Agriculture and Food Authority (AFA) invited KCPA as a farmer representative to various meeings 3. State dept of Coops invited KCPA to attend the Mark Up meeting by State Department of Trade in August 2019 4. The commissioner of Cooperatives invited KCPA to make a presentation on the proposed changes (as captured in the study) in the Cooperatives Act 5. Kenya Coffee Platform has established more women participation in leadership at policy level: e.g. appointment of two KCPA women members to KCP Steering committee 6. Several county level platforms are being created, which are important vessels to reach SHFs at grassroots levels 7. NACCU (National Union of Coffee Cooperatives) included women in their board and committed to recruit more women 8. Coffee growing counties e.g. Nyeri have been engaging Nature Kenya in the development of county climate change policies

29-04-2021: 1. Nature Kenya has a gender policy which guides engagement of staff and stakeholders in the project. We have ensured have ensured that gender segregated data is captured in all our project activities. 2. KCPA Members approved the board' proposal to restucture the organization during 2019 AGM held on 8/11/2019. The board has now developed the draft structure to be presented to the members for approval. Among other things, the proposed structure has a position for the youth and women representative right from the grass roots to the national level. 3. PS affirmed that the ministry is aware of the challenges that are facing the farmers and informed KCPA team that in partnership with world bank, the ministry was in the early stages of initiating a program aimed at addressing the challenges facing the farmers. He introduced KCPA to the program coordinator so that KCPA will participate at the implementation stage. PS also confirmed ministry of agriculture’s attendance for the breakfast meeting scheduled for 5/3/2020 to discuss the policy proposal 4. Large estate farmers who in 2015 left the association with the message that they do not get value for membership approached the KCPA management to be allowed back to the association. 5. 4/7/2020 - Disability Discovery Association of Kenya joined KCPA as an associate member. 6. On 15/07/2020, the CS issued a gazette notice that allowed the repealed coffee general regulations to operate for a period of one year to facilitate smooth transition.

title.narrative: Pathway 2: Research and pilots to create evidence for L&A

description.narrative: New knowledge & evidence is generated & widely accepted/ endorsed by key stakeholders

title.narrative: # of POs/CSOs/unions that use the evidence from research products to advocate for improved services or wages

comment.narrative: tbu

04-06-2019: 1. Living wage report 2. Economic Viability of Coffee Farming. Some of the key players, government and CSOs, have been using some of the critical findings from the EVoCF and are developing some action points around these findings with an intention of making farming sustainable. GCP is using such evidence from the report to show indeed the cost of production vs the income and at what point farmers make money. Similarly, several CSO have picked up the LW narrative with HIVOs and fairtrade using the Ankers methodology report to advocate for better wages for workers in agricultural sector.

29-04-2020: Nature Kenya is using the study report on Climate change and women as well as its study/research on Policy gaps at national and county govenrment level on matters climate change. KCPA advocacy work is based on a study which was commisioned to identify the gaps on co-operative act in Kenya.
29-04-2021: 1. Nature Kenya has engaged the five counties to attend a national policy dialogue on CSA/EBA in the coffee sector to share lessons learned from their engagement in the project.

title.narrative: # of new research products (reports, briefs) or evidence related to the needs of male and female farmers, smallholders and workers produced by partners

comment.narrative: tbu
29-04-2019: Living Wage study(better pay in practice), economic viablity of coffee farming by platform.

29-04-2020: Validation of 2 reports done and platform members actively particiated in it by sharing their inputs: 1. Embracing Innovative ways of information sharing by smallholder farmers. 2. Understanding the situation of small and medum estate farmers in relation to access to inputs and resources.

title.narrative: Ultimate Outcome 2: Policy changes & implementation

description.narrative: Policies are better in line with the needs of female and male farmers, smallholders and workers; Adequate implementation of policies;

title.narrative: DD1 # of ((inter)national) standards and policies implemented

description.narrative: Adequate implementation of policies

comment.narrative: 04-06-2019: 1:TheMinistry of Agriculture introduced a subsidy in the prices of fertilizer to be effected in March 2019
29-04-2021: 1. The Sector Budgetary Committee adopted a harmonised coffee sector budget to ensure adequate budgetary allocations to the coffee sector.

title.narrative: DD2 # of policy changes that UTZ /partners contributed to

description.narrative: Policies are better in line with the needs of (female) smallholders, (female) farmers and (female) farm workers, based on their needs and interests

comment.narrative: 04-06-2019: 1. KCPA presented the position paper on cooperatives law reforms to the ministry of cooperatives who have adopted it and presented it to parliament. 2: KCPA Coffee Roadmap 2018 -2019 was presented it to the Ministry of Agriculture. The roadmap was subsequently presented to the Cabinet for Approval

29-04-2020: 1) 20% of the recommendations in the policy paper by KCPA were taken up and incorporated in the amended version of the Coffee regulations 2)The government prioritised 4 short term goals under the big 4 agenda for the coffee sector which UTZ and the partners advocated for: - Inputs provision - Advance to farmers - Soil testing - accountability at producer organisation level.

29-04-2021: 1. On 24/1/2020 KCPA submitted her position on the coffee cherry revolving fund regulations, 2020. Two of the proposals that KCPA presented were adopted 2. On 14/4/2020, The ministry adopted the proposal while developing guidelines to guide the coffee farming operations and listed coffee as an essential service

Progress on this indicator is not expected for this period
10-01-2018: Progress on this indicator was not expected for this period
24-04-2018: Climate change & gender study; better pay in practice (Living wage)

title.narrative: Ultimate Outcome 3: Improvement of services

description.narrative: Services are better in line with the needs of female and male farmers, smallholders and workers; increased funding for services

title.narrative: DD1 # of new or improved government/company programs & services with budget allocation that are targeted and tailored to the needs of female and male smallholders and workers (related to the theme)

description.narrative: Services are better in line with the needs of (female) smallholders, (female) farmers and (female) farm workers, based on their needs and interests; increased funding for services

comment.narrative: 29-04-2020: 1. The different subsector actors united in the harmonization of a Climate Smart National Sustainability Curriculum (NSC) which is now being used for training. 2. Cabinet Secretary for Agriculture instructed the prioritization of lime fertilizer distribution to farmers and digitization of coffee cooperatives

29-04-2021: 1. Nature Kenya engaged CECs for Agriculture in the five counties to organize and lead one day hands on training of 25 agricultural extension officers and agronomists in each county on the EBA/CSA on farm practices. Facilitators were drawn from Nature Kenya, CRI, KCP, Climate Change Unit in the Ministry of Agriculture, Livestock, Fisheries and Cooperatives; and the National Climate Change Directorate in the Ministry of Environment and Forestry. 2. The Kenya Coffee Platform in partnership with County Governments facilitated pilot training of 1,000 coffee Master Trainers of both private and public extension service providers between December 2018 to December 2019 using the Kenya Coffee Sustainability Manual. This is the manual harmonised and developed in partnership with the platform. 3. Collaboration and support by the County Governments for the Master Trainers trained reaching out to County extension officers, lead farmers and farmers in training them using the harmonized training curriculum.
Target value for this period has not been defined yet.

title.narrative: Baseline Report

description.narrative: The baseline provides an elaborate context-analysis per country, containing details about capacity of partners and the current state regarding the thematic goals for L&A. The baseline focuses on three main areas: a. Description of baseline situation of context and stakeholders b. Baseline of outcomes of ToC c. Capacities assessment

title.narrative: # of baseline reports

comment.narrative: 1 baseline report is completed for Kenya
10-01-2018: 1 baseline report completed for Kenya

title.narrative: Pathway 1: UTZ engages in direct Lobby & Advocacy

description.narrative: UTZ engages in direct L&A, knowledge sharing, awareness raising and linking actors

title.narrative: DD3 # of issues brought forward by UTZ, partners and MSPs included in the agenda of public and private policy makers

description.narrative: Agenda setting

comment.narrative: tbu

29-04-2019: AWIC has been invited to make presentations to several coffee marketing cooperatives( i.e. Gikanda, Othaya, Baragwi, Kipkelion, Machakos Union, and county governments ( i.e Nakuru, Nyeri, Kirinyaga, Muranga and Kiambu) on the needs of female coffee farmers
29-04-2020: 1. Climate change adaptation strategies and resilience strategies including EBA strategies. 2. How to mainstream gender in the coffee supply chain

29-04-2021: 1. In October 2019, the County executives agreed to partner with Nature Kenya in planned subsequent awareness/sensitization meetings on EBA/CSA in the coffee sector and to nominate technical officers to facilitate appropriate sessions. This preceded all the other work in the engagement with the counties to engage with policy makers on CSA/EBA.

description.narrative: Discursive change

comment.narrative: 29-04-2020: 1. Economic Viability of coffee farming messages picked up by the government and companies. 2. Use of the national sustainability coffee curriculum picked by govt and companies.

29-04-2021: 1. Nature Kenya participated in national stakeholders forum on biodiversity and ecosystem services in agricultural landscapes in Kenya, where input was provided into the NBSAP and Kenya position paper to the CBD COP14.

description.narrative: Stakeholders ask and use UTZ knowledge, experience, tools for policy development and implementation (incl sourcing practices)

comment.narrative: tbu.
29-04-2019: In cooperative act study, NCCAP and Coffee reforms agenda

29-04-2020: 1. Coffee Sector Implementation Committee (CSIC) approached the platform to share inputs on the proposed coffee policy in Kenya. 2. The parliamentary committee on Agriculture approached the Kenya coffee platform and KCPA to share inputs on the new coffee rules being proposed in Kenya. 3. Nature Kenya is invited by KCP to give input to the Climate Smart National Sustainability Curriculum and KCP acknowledged the importance of climate change tools

29-04-2021: 1. On 6th August 2020, Nature Kenya received a request from the Ministry of Agriculture, Livestock, Fisheries and Cooperatives to provide input on project activities into the Climate Smart Agriculture - Multi stakeholder platform (CSA-MSP) within the national system of reporting climate change action.

title.narrative: DD3 # and type of panel discussions/ speaking opportunies

comment.narrative: 29-04-2020: 1)AFCA sustainability day (Kigali, Rwanda) and 2)GCP members assembly 3) The International coffee organization (ICO) invited KCP to participate and make a presentation during a session on price levels and volatility: towards sustainable path for the future of coffee 4). AFA invited AWIC to make a presentation at the ICO Council meeting 5) Export Processing Council (EPC)invited AWIC to make a presentations at the national coffee week and COMESA regional Coffee Week 6. The Parliamentary Committee on Agriculture allowed AWIC to present a policy paper on female coffee farmers

# curricula development processes supported by UTZ

description.narrative: Curriculum development is supported

comment.narrative: 10-01-2018: 1 curriculum development process supported by UTZ as part of the project Global Coffee Platform Institutional Support - Kenya [Theme: Farmer group strengthening]

29-04-2020: Managed to roll out the new coffee curriculum to 8 counties. Government and private sector extension officers also trained on this. With the roll out,atleast 120,000 farmers and almost 300 extension officers reached by end of 2019.The targeted counties include: Embu, Muranga, kirinyaga, Meru, Nyeri, Nakuru, Bungoma, Machakos

description.narrative: Curriculum is improved and widely accepted & endorsed by stakeholders

comment.narrative: tbu
29-04-2019: Within the platform and during the process of developing the National Sustainability Curriculum(NSC), we realised there is a need to make the NSC gender and climate smart sensitive.
29-04-2020: We've managed to make the national coffee sustainability curriculum both gender sensitive and EBA & climate smart.

title.narrative: Pathway 4: Support/strenghten MSPs, coalitions, networks, umbrella organizations
DD3 # of MSP's, coalitions, networks & umbrella organizations formed or strengthened

description.narrative: MSPs, coalitions, networks & umbrella organizations formed / with increased capacities & space for participation

comment.narrative: tbu

29-04-2019: The kenya coffee paltform brings together all the stakeholders together to discuss pre-competitive issues and since the launch of the platform(July 2018), people have felt free to discuss issues including with the policy makers. Similarly, our rpartners have used the platform to share the learnings as well as influence the agenda(Nature kenya ,AWIC and KCPA including other contracted consultants).
29-04-2021: 5 county platforms. Buy-in and support from the County Government and key coffee stakeholders – on the need for a functional County level social forums within the coffee sector.
30-04-2020: setting up 4 county platforms in progress

title.narrative: # of collaborative actions of CSOs with gov., private sector, other CSOs and MSPs

description.narrative: MSPs/coalitions/networks engage in L&A for issue;

comment.narrative: Target values for outcomes are currently being evaluated and will be updated.

29-04-2019: Development of econmic viability of coffee farming study, initiate coffee power talks (thematic discussions). The platform was also engaged by the national government to help them prioritise some of the key areas they want to focus on in the coffee sector. This was done in a collaborative way and the output of this was the inputs were highly considered in the big 4 agenda by the cabinet.

29-04-2020: 1. ISEAL collaborated with the platform to share knowledge the study results on living income with their study validated by the platform. 2. With the state department of co-operative, jointly developed a coffee database with a pilot done in Nyeri county targeting smallholder farmers. 3. Development of a soil testing and sampling methodology closely with Nakuru county. 4. Jointly co-chaired Nyeri county stakeholders meeting with the county executive. 5. Training of national extension officers in Kenya. Done collabortively with the following counties: Machakos, Kirinyaga, Nyeri, Muranga, Bungoma, Nakuru and Meru counties. 6. Power breakfast: There is increased networking and partnership among sector actors as a result of the Power Breakfast being organised by KCP

29-04-2021: 1. In October 2019, the County executives agreed to partner with Nature Kenya in planned subsequent awareness/sensitization meetings on EBA/CSA in the coffee sector and to nominate technical officers to facilitate appropriate sessions. This preceded all the other work in the engagement with the counties to engage with policy makers on CSA/EBA. 2. On 6th August 2020, Nature Kenya received a request from the Ministry of Agriculture, Livestock, Fisheries and Cooperatives to provide input on project activities into the Climate Smart Agriculture - Multi stakeholder platform (CSA-MSP) within the national system of reporting climate change action.

title.narrative: # of joint statements issued/publications produced/agreements made

description.narrative: MSPs/coalitions/networks engage in L&A for issue;

comment.narrative: 29-04-2020: We’ve made public some of the recommedations of the Economic Viability of Farming report and many stakeholders are using the findings, including the government in decision making. Similarly, the use of the NCSC is gaining momentum with companies and govt official adopting it.

29-04-2021: 1. In July 2020, acceptance by the 5 Counties to convene high level dialogue to prioritise EBA/CSA. Meetings were convened. - one meeting per County in the 5 Counties. 2. At the Inter-African Coffee Organization annual meeting in Nairobi, KCP organized a sustainability seminar where there were presentations from success stories of farmers who have ventured into coffee farming as a business. 3. KCP participated at the validation workshop of the National Coffee Policy facilitated by Coffee Sector Implementation Committee.
Progress on this indicator is not expected in this period

title.narrative: DD3 # of sector platforms including issues proposed by UTZ and/or partners on the agenda

description.narrative: MSPs/coalitions/networks include issues in their agenda

comment.narrative: 29-04-2020: We've managed to influence the agenda on matters gender within the coffee supply chain within the platform. Similarly, we've managed to highlight issues on climate change and ecosystem based adaptation plans in the platform.
29-04-2021: KCP (Kenya Coffee Platform)
tbu

title.narrative: # of Pos/CSOs that use the evidence from implementing UTZ tools to advocate for improved services

description.narrative: Pos/ CSO's /Unions engage in L&A for improved service delivery

comment.narrative: Target values for outcomes are currently being evaluated and will be updated.

29-04-2019: Developing living wage models for coffee farms using different matrixes as outlined in the living wage study. Mainstreaming gender within the diferrent supply chains using the tools from the gender coaches session.
29-04-2020: 1. Partners are using the model recommendations to negociate commercial and LW based pricing 2. Coffee farmers began to request for the payment of a living income
